[[File:Máximo Jerez.jpg|thumb|Máximo Jerez monument in front of the Cathedral in León, Nicaragua.]]

'''Máximo Jerez Tellería''' (8 June 1818 in [[León, Nicaragua]] – 12 August 1881 in [[Washington, D.C.]], USA) was a 19th-century [[Nicaragua]]n [[politician]], [[lawyer]] and [[military leader]].

He is considered to be one of the greatest [[Liberalism|Liberal]] political thinkers in Nicaraguan history. He was a leader of the movement towards Central American unity.<ref>Gamez, Jose D., ''El León del Istmo Apuntamientos para la Biografía de Máximo Jerez'', Guadalupe LTDA, 1989, Colombia.</ref><ref>
Wolfe, Justin. ''The Everyday Nation-State: Community & Ethnicity in Nineteenth-Century Nicaragua.'' Lincoln: The University of Nebraska Press, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-8032-4818-2}}</ref>

Together with [[Francisco Castellón Sanabria]], he participated in bringing to Nicaragua the [[Filibuster (military)|filibuster]] of [[William Walker (filibuster)|William Walker]] and on 31 October 1855 was designated Minister of Foreign Relations in Walker's provisional government, led officially by [[Patricio Rivas]]. He ran for the presidency in 1856, but no candidate obtained an absolute majority. By Walker's decision, provisional President Rivas summoned new elections on 10 March 1856, but countermanded the decree on 14 March, and broke relations with Walker.

On 23 January 1857 Jerez formed a dual Junta government with the Conservative [[Tomás Martínez]] and they acted jointly as Presidents of Nicaragua, from 24 June 1857 to 19 October or 15 November 1857.<ref name=\mined\">{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009181920/http://www.mined.gob.ni/gobern15.php|title=Gobernantes de Nicaragua|date=9 December 2012|publisher=Ministerio de Educación}}</ref> In his subsequent career as Minister Plenipotentiary of Nicaragua to [[Costa Rica]]
column5: he signed on 15 April 1858
column6: the [[Cañas–Jerez Treaty]] that defined the boundaries between the two countries.

column1: In 1876 he organized from [[El Salvador]] an expedition to overthrow the provisional government of [[Pedro Joaquín Chamorro Alfaro]]
In the city of León there is a statue in his honor.

'''Ryszard Iwon Terlecki''' (born September 2, 1949) is a Polish politician, the [[Caucus|Parliamentary Caucus Head]] of the [[Law and Justice]] party. Terlecki, a [[historian]] and [[Professor (highest academic rank)|professor]] of humanities, lectures at the [[Pontifical University of John Paul II]]. He is a Member of the [[Sejm]], serving since 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official website|url=http://ryszardterlecki.pl/|website=ryszardterlecki.pl|accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref>

==Personal life==
He is the son of the writer and journalist [[Olgierd Terlecki]] who was a secret collaborator of the Security Service in PRL for 35 year and his wife Janina. In his youth, he was a participant in the [[hippie movement]] and one of the precursors of this youth subculture in Poland. He was known in the environment under the pseudonym ''Pies'' (pol. ''Dog'').<ref>[http://www.tvp.info/22579052/byly-hipis-zostal-szefem-klubu-pis-jego-eksdziewczyna-kora-opowiadala-jak-razem-palili-trawke Były hipis został szefem klubu PiS. '''Evolve Foundation''' is an Indian [[social enterprise]] based in [[Dehradun]], [[Uttarakhand]]. It is founded by [[Nupur Agarwal]] along with Abhinav Ahluwalia in 2016. The [[Organization|organisation]] deals with producing [[Environmentally friendly|eco-friendly]] plantable stationary along with uplifting rural villages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/dehradun/social-entrepreneurs-show-the-way-in-doing-sustainable-biz/articleshow/74324358.cms|title=‘Social entrepreneurs’ show the way in doing sustainable biz {{!}} Dehradun News - Times of India|last=Feb 27|first=TNN {{!}}|last2=2020|website=The Times of India|language=en|access-date=2020-04-09|last3=Ist|first3=04:32}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youthkiawaaz.com/2018/12/story-of-a-social-entrepreneur/|title=Nupur Agarwal’s Evolve Foundation Uplifts Rural Farming In Uttarakhand|date=2018-12-04|website=Youth Ki Awaaz|language=en|access-date=2020-04-09}}</ref>

He studied [[physics]] at the [[University of Turin]] and holds a PhD in theoretical [[particle physics]]. ''The Solitude of Prime Numbers'', his first novel, has sold over a million copies and was translated into thirty languages. The Italian language [[The Solitude of Prime Numbers|film]] based on the novel was released in September 2010. The '''rue Sainte-Catherine''', a 1.2 km long pedestrian street, is the main shopping street in [[Bordeaux]], [[France]].

Located on the former roman [[cardo]], this street is one of two main lines running through the historic part of the city. It cuts the center following a North-South axis linking the place de la Comédie where the [[Grand Théâtre (Bordeaux)|Grand Theatre]] stands to the Place de la Victoire. The rue Sainte-Catherine and neighborhoods located to the West are very commercial areas. It became a pedestrian street for most of its length between 1976 and 1977 and then in full in 1984. It is often billed as the longest pedestrian street in Europe.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} It was completely refurbished between 2000 and 2003 in a project by [[Jean-Michel Wilmotte]].

At the center of the rue Sainte-Catherine you find place Saint-Project ([[Auvergnat (dialect)|Auvergnat]] bishop died in 674). The cross intersection was restored in 1977, it was at the centre of a cemetery since 1392. The church was located to the south and its bell tower still remains. The fountain was made around 1715.

At the top of the street is one of the entrances to the Galerie Bordelaise, a shopping mall which opened in 1834.

At the junction of the street and the cours Alsace-Lorraine, a [[bas-relief]] indicates the presence of two underground rivers that are flowing into the [[Garonne]]: the [[Peugue]] and [[Devèze River|Devèze]].

== Transport ==
The rue Sainte-Catherine is served by [[Bordeaux Tramway Line A|Line A]] of the [[Tramway de Bordeaux]], [[Station Sainte-Catherine (Tram de Bordeaux)|station Sainte-Catherine]], and [[Bordeaux Tramway Line B|Line B]], stations [[Station Grand Théâtre (Tram de Bordeaux)|Grand Théâtre]] and  [[Station Victoire (Tram de Bordeaux)|Victoire]].

'''Carlo II Malatesta''' ({{Circa|1390}} – 14 November 1438) was an Italian politician and [[condottiero]]. He was lord of [[Pesaro]], [[Gradara]], [[Senigallia]], [[Fossombrone]] and [[Civitanova Marche]]. He was the son of [[Malatesta IV Malatesta]] and [[Elisabetta da Varano]].

==Life==
In 1409 he followed his father to [[Florence]] to fight against the [[King of Naples]]'s army. In 1421 he fought for the [[Papal States]] against [[Perugia]] and for a short time for the Florentines against [[Milan]]. He and his brother [[Galeazzo Malatesta|Galeazzo]] were captured at [[Gradara]] in 1424 after their father's and their cousin Carlo's defeat at [[Zagonara]] by the [[Visconti of Milan|Visconti]]. Carlo joined the Visconti army and in 1426 fought in [[Romagna]] against the Anti-Visconti League.

In 1427 he was made captain general of the Visconti armies, putting him in command of 1,200 cavalry in the battle against [[Francesco Bussone]]. The Visconti force was defeated at [[Pizzighettone]] and Carlo was captured again until being freed when the two sides made peace. In 1428 Carlo married [[Colonna family|Vittoria Colonna]], [[Pope Martin V]]'s niece, but the couple remained childless. In 1430 he fought against [[Rimini]] but was defeated and fled from [[Sigismondo Pandolfo Malatesta]]. Shortly afterwards he defended [[Bologna]] against an attack by [[Anton Galeazzo Bentivoglio]].

In 1431 a revolt broke out in [[Pesaro]], forcing Carlo to retreat to [[Fossombrone]] then to Gradara and elsewhere. In 1433 he helped the Montefeltro and the Visconti reconquer their own lands. The resulting treaty brought peace between the Papal States and the two Malatesta brothers, Carlo and Galeazzo. Carlo returned to Pesaro on 24 September and killed all those who had revolted two years earlier.

'''Carlo II Malatesta''' (c.1390 – 14 November 1438) was an Italian politician and [[condottiero]]. He was lord of [[Pesaro]], [[Gradara]], [[Senigallia]], [[Fossombrone]] and [[Civitanova Marche]]. He was the son of [[Malatesta IV Malatesta]] and [[Elisabetta da Varano]].

==Life==
In 1409 he followed his father to [[Florence]] to fight against the [[king of Naples]]'s army. In 1421 he fought for the [[Papal States]] against [[Perugia]] and for a short time for the Florentines against [[Milan]]. He and his brother [[Galeazzo Malatesta|Galeazzo]] were captured at [[Gradara]] in 1424 after their father's and their cousin Carlo's defeat at [[Zagonara]] by the [[Visconti of Milan|Visconti]]. Carlo joined the Visconti army and in 1426 fought in [[Romagna]] against the Anti-Visconti League.

In 1427 he was made captain general of the Visconti armies, putting him in command of 1,200 cavalry in the battle against [[Francesco Bussone]]. The Visconti force was defeated at [[Pizzighettone]] and Carlo was captured again until being freed when the two sides made peace. In 1428 Carlo married [[Colonna family|Vittoria Colonna]], [[pope Martin V]]'s niece, but the couple remained childless. In 1430 he fought against [[Rimini]] but was defeated and fled from [[Sigismondo Pandolfo Malatesta]]. Shortly afterwards he defended [[Bologna]] against an attack by [[Anton Galeazzo Bentivoglio]].

In 1431 a revolt broke out in [[Pesaro]], forcing Carlo to retreat to [[Fossombrone]] then to Gradara and elsewhere. In 1433 he helped the Montefeltro and the Visconti reconquer their own lands. The resulting treaty brought peace between the Papal States and the two Malatesta brothers, Carlo and Galeazzo. Carlo returned to Pesaro on 24 September and killed all those who had revolted two years earlier.

The '''Wellington West Coast and Taranaki Regiment''' was a Territorial Force unit of the [[New Zealand Army]]. It was originally formed in 1948 by the amalgamation of two separate regiments:
*'''Wellington West Coast Regiment''' (previously the 7th (Wellington West Coast Rifles) Regiment)
*'''Taranaki Regiment'''  (previously the 11th (Taranaki Rifles) Regiment)

The regiment became a TF battalion of the [[Royal New Zealand Infantry Regiment]] in 1964 during the reorganisation of the army. This was until the later reorganisation of 1999, which saw the TF battalions split from the RNZIR to become multi-function ''battalion groups''. The Wellington, West Coast and Taranaki Regiment became the 5th Wellington, West Coast and Taranaki Battalion Group, with the following unit types:
*[[Military engineering|Engineers]] – 1 Field Squadron, [[Corps of Royal New Zealand Engineers|RNZE]]
*[[Infantry]]
*[[Battlefield medicine|Medical]]
*[[Logistics]]
*[[Pipe band|Pipes and Drums of the Wellington West Coast and Taranaki Regiment]]

In December 2012 the regiment was amalgamated with the [[Wellington_(City_of_Wellington's_Own)_and_Hawke's_Bay_Regiment|7th Wellington and Hawke's Bay Battalion]] to form the [[5th/7th Battalion, Royal New Zealand Infantry Regiment]] (5/7 RNZIR).

==Battle honours==
*New Zealand
*South Africa
*First World War: Somme 1916–18, Messines 1917, Ypres 1917, Bapaume 1918, Hindenburg Line, Landing at ANZAC, France and Flanders 1916–1918, Sari Bair 1915, Gallipoli 1915, Egypt 1915–1916
*Second World War: Greece 1941, Crete, Sidi Rezegh 1941, Minquar Qaim, El Alamein, North Africa 1940–1943, Cassino I, The Senio, Italy 1943–45, Solomons

The regiment is one of two unique regiments of the Commonwealth, in that it is one of two regiments to have its own country's name as a battle honour. This dates from the service of the Taranaki Volunteer Rifle Corps, from which the Taranaki Regiment is descended, during the [[New Zealand Wars]], specifically in the [[Battle of Waireka]].

The other unit to share this honour is the [[Cape Town Highlanders Regiment]], a reserve mechanised unit of [[South African Army]].

The '''Wellington West Coast and Taranaki Regiment''' was a Territorial Force unit of the [[New Zealand Army]]. It was originally formed in 1948 by the amalgamation of two separate regiments:
*'''Wellington West Coast Regiment''' (previously the 7th (Wellington West Coast Rifles) Regiment)
*'''Taranaki Regiment'''  (previously the 11th (Taranaki Rifles) Regiment)

The regiment became a TF battalion of the [[Royal New Zealand Infantry Regiment]] in 1964 during the reorganisation of the army. This was until the later reorganisation of 1999, which saw the TF battalions split from the RNZIR to become multi-function '''battalion groups'''. The Wellington, West Coast and Taranaki Regiment became the 5th Wellington, West Coast and Taranaki Battalion Group, with the following unit types:
*[[Engineers]] – 1 Field Squadron, [[Corps of Royal New Zealand Engineers|RNZE]]
*[[Infantry]]
*[[Battlefield medicine|Medical]]
*[[Logistics]]
*[[Pipe band|Pipes and Drums of the Wellington West Coast and Taranaki Regiment]]
In December 2012 the Regiment was amalgamated with the [[Wellington_(City_of_Wellington's_Own)_and_Hawke's_Bay_Regiment|7th Wellington and Hawke's Bay Battalion]] to form the [[5th/7th Battalion, Royal New Zealand Infantry Regiment]] (5/7 RNZIR).

==Battle honours==
*New Zealand
*South Africa
*First World War: Somme 1916–18, Messines 1917, Ypres 1917, Bapaume 1918, Hindenburg Line, Landing at ANZAC, France and Flanders 1916–1918, Sari Bair 1915, Gallipoli 1915, Egypt 1915–1916
*Second World War: Greece 1941, Crete, Sidi Rezegh 1941, Minquar Qaim, El Alamein, North Africa 1940–1943, Cassino I, The Senio, Italy 1943–45, Solomons

The regiment is one of two unique regiments of the Commonwealth, in that it is one of two regiments to have its own country's name as a battle honour. This dates from the service of the Taranaki Volunteer Rifle Corps, from which the Taranaki Regiment is descended, during the [[New Zealand Wars]], specifically in the [[Battle of Waireka]].

The other unit to share this honour is the [[Cape Town Highlanders Regiment]], a reserve mechanised unit of [[South African Army]].

==Alliances==

'''Vinod Bhayana''' is an Indian politician who is the [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (India)|MLA]] of [[Hansi]] constituency in [[Hisar district|Hisar District]] in [[Haryana|Harayana]], India.  He won reelection in 2019 by 22,200 votes. 

In his previous term, Bhayana also served as Chief Parliamentary Secretary in the [[Haryana government|Haryana Government]] under Jails, Order and law and Electricity portfolios.

==Political career==
Bhayana started his political career in [[Lohari Ragho]] , where he was elected [[Sarpanch]] five times. His father, Bhai Mahesh Chandar Bhayana, was also Sarpanch there. Vinod Bhayana was elected as MLA from Hansi in 2009 and reelected in  2019.

In 2016, he was booked under the provisions of the Prevention of Corruption Act in connection with the alleged cash-for-change of land use (CLU) scam.<ref>https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/haryana-five-ex-legislators-booked-in-change-of-land-use-scam/articleshow/50783441.cms?from=mdr</ref>

==Contributions==
During his time in office, Bhayana built the largest Water Tank in Hansi.  He founded master's degree courses in Nehru college, Hansi. and created the Sh Hukam Chand Jain Park

Bhayana contributed to the building of six water boosting stations and two [[Sewage treatment|sewerage treatment]] plants in Hansi.  He inaugurated the four-lane highway between Hansi and [[Rohtak]], along with the Hansi to Rohtak railway line

==Family==
In 1984, Bhayana married Sunita Bhayana; the couple two sons and one daughter,  Anshul Bhayana, Sahil Bhayana and Supriya Nagpal. They live in Bank colony Hansi.<ref>[http://haryanaassembly.gov.in/MLADetails.aspx?MLAID=736 Haryana Vidhan Sabha MLA]</ref><ref>[http://myneta.info/ha2009/candidate.php?candidate_id=399 My Neta]</ref><ref>[http://www.elections.in/haryana/assembly-constituencies/hansi.html Sitting and Previous MLAs from Hansi Assembly Constituency]</ref>

'''Social Income''' is a [[non-profit organization|nonprofit organization]] operating in West Africa that helps people living in [[poverty]] by making [[unconditional cash transfer]]s to them via mobile phone. Currently Social Income transfers funds to people in need in [[Sierra Leone]].

== History ==

Social Income initiative was launched 2019 in [[Zurich]], Switzerland. It started as an initiative by [[Random Institute]] to support artists in need in underdeveloped countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://randominstitute.org/event/social-income|title=Social Income|website=Random Institute|access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref> In 2020 the initiative was expanded through a residency program offered by the independent foundation Stroom, [[The Hague]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stroom.nl/activiteiten/manifestatie.php?m_id=1788867|title=Our House, your Home – Stroom|website= Stroom|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref>

== Activity ==
Social Income is a system of [[wealth redistribution]] in the form of unconditional, long-term cash payments<ref name=ft>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/a1101f00-e8fd-11e2-aead-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2YrNfbJGn | title =The Undercover Economist: How to give money away |last = Harford|first = Tim|date = July 12, 2013}}</ref> for people in need, paid for by volunteer contributors from across the world. The project's approach to redistribution is taking the enormous income gap between global north and south as a starting point. Currently Social Income's transfers funds to people in need in Sierra Leone.

== Funding ==
In contrast to [[Universal Basic Income]], which would be provided by a state or government, Social Income is provided from person to person. Individual contributors pay 1% of their monthly paycheck, which is added to the social income fund and directly deposited to a recipient's mobile phone.
